newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian '96/97 winter oilseed crop seen up-trade.
newsitem.headline: Indian '96/97 winter oilseed crop seen up-trade.

text.p: India's Kharif or winter oilseed crop in the 1996/97 (November-October) season is expected to be 11.91 million tonnes, marginally up from the previous year's 11.43 million, a top trade body said on Sunday.

The Central Organisation for Oils Industry and Trade (COOIT) said, at a national convention on oilseeds in the southern city of Bangalore, that the soybean crop however would be lower at 4.06 million tonnes in 1996/97 against 4.45 million in the earlier year.
The COOIT estimated groundnut crop during the same period at 5.7 million tonnes against 4.95 million in 1995/96.
"The highlight of the oilseeds crop this year has been groundnut," said S.T. Parikh, COOIT convener for crop estimates.
He said the western state of Gujarat accounted for most of the rise with 1.7 million tonnes in the current season against 1.0 million in the previous season.
India's oilseeds production comprises Kharif or winter crop and Rabi or summer harvest.
Delegates to the COOIT convention estimated overall crop in the current year would be around 21.90 million tonnes against 20.98 million in the previous year.
They said the 1996/97 monsoon which helped the Kharif crop would also be helpful to the Rabi harvest which would be sown early next year and harvested in April-May.
"Our estimates of Rabi will be around 10 million against 9.55 million in the previous year," said a top COOIT official.
Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda, who inaugurated the convention, promised to look into the COOIT demand for allowing free imports of oilseeds.
He said the government would consider allowing free import of oilseeds provided the farmers were protected and consumers benefited from the move.
Gowda said the government would also consider removing controls on storage of oilseeds and revamping of tax structure.
He said the acreage under India's oilseeds crop rose to 26 million hectares from 19 million in the last 10 years.
The oilseeds productivity per hectare had also gone up to 800 kg from 500 kg. "But this is not sufficient to meet the growing demand for oils," he told the convention.
